definition[0]: the total after a lot of different figures or points have been added together
example[0]: In the aggregate (=as a group or in total), women outlive men by 7 or more years.
example[2]: The smaller minorities got an aggregate of 1,327 votes.
definition[1]: sand or small stones that are used in making concrete
definition[2]: being the total amount of something after all the figures or points have been added together
example[3]: an increase in the aggregate production
definition[3]: to be a particular amount when added together
example[4]: Sheila’s earnings from all sources aggregated £100,000.
definition[4]: to put different amounts, pieces of information etc together to form a group or a total
example[5]: A wife’s income is no longer aggregated with that of her husband.
explanation[0]: Aggregate  is usually passive in this meaning, when used as a transitive verb
definition[5]: the total after a lot of different parts or figures have been added together
example[6]: If workers seek greater increases in wages, they will in the aggregate (=in total) bring about higher inflation.
definition[6]: one of the measurements used when calculating the amount of money in an economy at a particular time
example[7]: M2, the aggregate most closely tracked by the Federal Reserve Board
example[8]: The conglomerate reported an aggregate loss of 1.2 billion Australian dollars.
example[9]: Analysts expect aggregate earnings of the top 500 companies to be down 1%.
